newsitem.title: USA: US West Coast crudes drop, Canadian crude watched.
newsitem.headline: US West Coast crudes drop, Canadian crude watched.

text.p: Outright prices for U.S West Coast light crude dropped in line with technical selling of crude futures and a weaker fundamental outlook for heating oil, traders said, but buyers watched foreign sources closely.
West Coast buyers of Alaska North Slope (ANS) crude avoided the grade Friday, after two late-week deals tightened the differential 10 cents for April cargoes.
Buyers said they would look overseas, with one bringing in 400,000 barrels of Colombia South Blend in April. The cargo was priced on a WTI-related formula, the trader said.
They said ANS might hit last year's level of -$0.60 cents.
Although a Washington refiner said they feared Canadian light crude imports would drop, removing an important ANS alternative, some traders said March supplies were high.
"It seems to be higher than a lot of people were expecting," a Canadian trader said, noting the price for light sweet grades could range $1.15 to $1.25 over WTI.
While the ANS price remains high, traders said the only alternative grade which could contain ANS, is Indonesian.
"It's even pricier than Canada," a trader said.
Talk circulated that imports into Chicago and eastern Canada would ease demand on the Interprovincial Pipe Line and allow more Canadian grades to move West.
Desite the tighter discount, ANS outright prices fell to $19.30/19.50 a barrel, off 50 cents from Thursday.
Line 63 prices stood unchanged at postings plus $0.95 - $1.05.
Kern River heavy crude prices fell, after two major California oil companies lowered postings.
A deal was heard done earlier this week at 0.45 cents a barrel under heavy postings, a sharp increase over previous discounts.
